citeinfo.title: Location and land cover uncertainty associated with stop-level data from the North American Breeding Bird Survey (BBS)
Informative priors can account for location uncertainty in stop-level analyses of the North American Breeding Bird Survey (BBS), allowing fine-scale ecological analyses

descript.abstract: The North American Breeding Bird Survey (BBS) (https://www.pwrc.usgs.gov/bbs/) has counted birds annually for over fifty-five years. Survey 'routes' each consist of 50 'stops' (point counts) placed along a route path. Inter-stop distances and stop locations can vary from route to route and from year to year, and precise locations of each stop are not typically recorded. This data set (and the associated R script) includes quantified uncertainty in BBS annual point count locations using digitized estimates of stop locations from the central United States. It also includes the necessary components to calculate the resulting land cover uncertainty for each annual point count (i.e., stop) and facilitates incorporation of this uncertainty into Bayesian multi-species hierarchical models to predict stop-level BBS bird detections. It can be used to repeat the authors' analyses, or to produce additional analyses of BBS data from other regions, for other bird species, or for other covariates. Files in this dataset include (1) spatial coordinates of autogenerated points placed every 40 m along BBS routes in the central United States ('Autogenerated_BBS_points.csv'), (2) the autogenerated point number nearest each digitized estimate of BBS route-stop-year combination (although the year is typically unknown; 'BBS_stops_nearest_autogen_point.csv'), (3) location uncertainty along BBS route paths of BBS stops by stop number, in terms both of autogenerated point numbers and route path distance ('BBS_stop_location_uncertainty.csv'), (4) locations and nearest autogenerated point numbers for some BBS stop locations that were recorded using GPS in known years ('WI_GPS_BBS_stops.csv'), and (5) a series of land cover habitat summary files (one for each relevant year) for BBS routes in Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Michigan that summarizes land cover within a 400 m radius of each autogenerated point on these routes (e.g., 'habSubset_nlcd_2004.csv'). Land cover classes are based on merged cover classes from the National Land Cover Database (NLCD). This data set can best be understood in the context of the associated R code (https://doi.org/10.5066/P1HY6LDF) and manuscript.
descript.purpose: These data were collected to quantify estimates of location and land cover uncertainty associated with stop-level bird data from the North American Breeding Bird Survey (BBS) (https://www.pwrc.usgs.gov/bbs/). It can be used to understand, interpret, or analyze these uncertainties. Note that these uncertainties likely vary by region and so these data will be most applicable within the region covered by the data release. Users of this data release (and associated R code: https://doi.org/10.5066/P1HY6LDF) could, for example, use our autogenerated point locations along BBS route paths in the central United States to produce their own habitat (i.e., land cover) estimates as desired. They could then use our stop location uncertainty distributions to estimate habitat uncertainty for each BBS stop and include this uncertainty in models. It is important to note that BBS estimated stop locations included in this data release are estimates based on e.g., observer notes and stop descriptions and do not represent BBS data products. The location of annual point counts, and the associations between annual counts and a given stop number, cannot be assumed to be consistent from year to year. Locations and stop numbers often vary through time, and the survey year(s) associated with most estimated stop locations in this dataset is unknown. Therefore, digitized estimates of stop locations included here should be used only to quantify variation in stop locations among routes. They cannot be assumed to be associated with BBS bird count data from a given year. They are most appropriately used in aggregate, e.g., to quantify uncertainty.

idinfo.accconst: None. Please see 'Distribution Info' for details.
idinfo.useconst: None. Users are advised to read the dataset's metadata thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations.
idinfo.datacred: This project was funded through the USGS Natural Resources Preservation Program (NRPP). See associated publications and data release for additional acknowledgments. We thank Mikey Lutmerding and Keith Pardieck from the U.S. Geological Survey Eastern Ecological Science Center for supplying scans of paper BBS route maps and Glen Fredlund from University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee for facilitating the GIS work digitizing Wisconsin survey information. Wayne Thogmartin provided digitized location information for Illinois and Nathan Stricker provided the same for Ohio. Jeffrey Hostetler and David Ziolkowski Jr assisted with interpretation of BBS data. We are grateful to the many Breeding Bird Survey volunteer observers who make this work possible. Craig Young and Thomas Parr for facilitated this collaboration with National Park Service. We thank William Beatty for reviewing data and metadata, and Jessica Stanton for reviewing associated code and a related manuscript. In-kind support was provided by National Park Service, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, and U.S. Geological Survey. Any use of trade, firm, or product names is for descriptive purposes only and does not imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.
idinfo.native: This dataset was produced in R (v4.3.3) in Windows 10.

citeinfo.title: 2022 Release - North American Breeding Bird Survey Dataset (1966-2021)
ebirdst: Tools for loading, plotting, mapping and analysis of eBird Status and Trends data products. R package version 2.2021.1.
North American Breeding Bird Survey (BBS) stop-level uncertainty

attracc.attraccr: Autogenerated points fall directly on BBS route paths. Digitized estimates of stop locations for North American Breeding Bird Survey (BBS) routes are not collected by the BBS and vary in location accuracy and in currentness (i.e., applicable year). They are typically based on a third-party (i.e., other researchers) inspecting observer notes and stop descriptions, which are not always updated annually. They are therefore not paired with a known year and should not be assumed to correspond to BBS bird count data from any particular year. Rather, these estimated locations are here used only to quantify overall uncertainty and variation in stop placement, and so any errors and imprecisions should have minimal impact on our data quality. Land cover values are based on the National Land Cover Database (NLCD) and so are as accurate as that source and the underlying location uncertainty allow.

dataqual.logic: Values are all present and fall within expected ranges. We have checked for data duplication and missing values.
dataqual.complete: We included all BBS routes from our study time frame in the geographic study area except those excluded as detailed in the processing steps.

horizpa.horizpar: Autogenerated points fall directly on the underlying BBS route paths and are therefore dependent on route path accuracy.

srcinfo.srccontr: Used to summarize land cover along BBS routes.

srcinfo.srccontr: Combined with other stop location datasets to quantify stop location uncertainty.

citeinfo.title: 2022 Release - North American Breeding Bird Survey Dataset (1966-2021)

srcinfo.srccontr: Used to extract BBS route numbers, route shapefile, and route start points

procstep.procdesc: We obtained BBS route paths from U.S. Geological Survey (2012) and start points from the BBS dataset (Ziolkowski Jr et al. 2022). We began with all routes in our 17-state focal region (n = 1,361, then removed routes that were not conducive to our method of quantifying location uncertainty. We excluded non-random (i.e., 900-series) routes (n= 72), non-linear routes (with forks, ‘T’s, loops, or multiple GIS line segments; n = 42), route paths greater than 1000 m from their designated start points (n = 26), and routes with abnormally long (>48 km; n = 79) or short (<37 km; n = 5) BBS route paths. Finally, we removed routes for which digitized estimated stop locations indicated a direction of travel opposite that indicated by route start points (n = 18; 2.8% of all digitized routes). We thus retained 1,119 routes (82%). In preparation for quantifying the distributions of digitized estimated stop locations along BBS routes and extracting corresponding land cover distributions, we first used ArcGIS Pro 3.1.2 to generate sequentially numbered points every 40 m along each route. These points (hereafter ‘autogenerated points’) were numbered, e.g., 1-1000 for a 40 km route, starting at the end of the route nearest the start point. These autogenerated points therefore function as a measure of distance along a route path (hereafter ‘route distance’), such that, e.g., autogenerated point 201 on any route is (201-1) * 40 m = 8000 m from the starting end of the route path. This produced our file of autogenerated points: 'Autogenerated_BBS_points.csv'

To quantify uncertainty in annual point count locations for each stop number (1–50) across BBS routes, we assumed that digitized estimates of stop locations were representative of the overall variation in stop locations along BBS routes in the region. We used digitized location estimates available from 13 of 17 states in our focal region in the central United States. This includes digitized estimated stop locations from Ohio (Stricker 2012, unpublished), Illinois (Thogmartin 2000, unpublished) (Thogmartin 2002), Wisconsin (Anich & Striegel 2019, unpublished), parts of Missouri, Arkansas, and Oklahoma (Twedt 2020), and Kansas, Nebraska, South Dakota, North Dakota, and parts of Colorado, Wyoming, and Montana (Niemuth et al. 2017). In total, we used 25,078 estimated stop locations across 568 routes. Refer to Supplementary Material Table S1 for routes for which digitized stop location estimates were used by state, and for corresponding years and digitization methods.
Digitized estimates of stop locations for North American Breeding Bird Survey (BBS) routes are not collected by the BBS and vary in location accuracy and currentness (i.e., applicable year). They are typically based on a third-party (i.e., other researchers) inspecting observer notes and stop descriptions, which are not always updated on an annual basis. They are therefore not paired with a known year and should not be assumed to correspond to BBS bird count data from any particular year. They are most appropriately used in aggregate, e.g., to quantify uncertainty.
For each of these digitized estimated stop locations, we then located the nearest autogenerated point on the appropriate route. Because digitized estimates of stop locations vary in their placement along each route, the nearest autogenerated point to each stop number will also vary by route. This produced a file of the nearest autogenerated point to each stop location: 'BBS_stops_nearest_autogen_point.csv'
We extracted the distributions of autogenerated point numbers nearest each BBS stop number across the entire dataset of digitized estimated stops. This produced binned distributions (40 m bins, corresponding to spacing of autogenerated points) of distance along routes for each stop number (1–50). BBS stops beyond stop 45 were often beyond the end of 40 km route lines (e.g., on 28% of routes for stop 50), so we eliminated stops 46–50 from further analysis. We also excluded all stops for which the distance to the nearest autogenerated point was >200 m (n = 457; 1.8% of all stops), which typically indicated a minor route deviation. A subset of digitized estimated stop locations (n = 837) was collected using GPS units in a known year in Wisconsin, and these were used as a validation test of our method (described in a later step).
This produced a file with the distribution of autogenerated points for each BBS stop number: 'BBS_stop_location_uncertainty_autogen_point_numbers.csv'

To quantify land cover uncertainty at each BBS annual point count event using these estimated stop location uncertainty distributions, we first defined our land cover covariates of interest. We used NLCD layers (Dewitz 2021) for the year closest to each BBS bird survey year and merged some NLCD categories to simplify land cover classes for our analyses (described below). For modeling, we chose to focus on three broad land cover categories – forest, grass/hay, and development – to assess their effects on bird occurrences. We defined our radius of interest as 400 m, which minimizes overlap between adjacent stops, corresponds to the BBS protocol maximum aural detection distance, and is consistent with other studies examining local-scale habitat effects on birds. We then calculated proportion cover (proportion of 30-m NLCD cells of that cover class) within a 400-m radius for each of our merged land cover classes. We did this for each autogenerated point on each route for each NLCD year (2004, 2008, 2011, 2013, 2016), using the focal statistics tool in ArcGIS Pro 3.1.
We merged NLCD land cover classes as follows: forest: included Deciduous Forest; Evergreen Forest; Mixed Forest; Woody Wetlands grasshay: included Grassland/Herbaceous; Pasture/Hay; Sedge/Herbaceous devAll: included Developed, Open Space; Developed, Low Intensity; Developed, Medium Intensity; Developed, High Intensity crops: included Cultivated Crops wet: included Emergent Herbaceous Wetlands shrub: included Shrub/Scrub
This produced a summary of land cover within a 400 m radius for each year that we include (2004, 2008, 2011, 2013, 2016): i.e., 'habSubset_nlcd_2004.csv', with one file for each included land cover (i.e., NLCD) year.

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing data. This file shows, for many digitized estimates of BBS stop locations from a given (usually unspecified) year, which of our autogenerated points along the relevant route was closest to that stop, and the distance between the estimated stop location and nearest autogenerated point. Includes all routes from the central United States study region that were conducive to our method and had digitized estimated stop locations available. Autogenerated point coordinates for each route and available in 'Autogenerated_BBS_points.csv'. Distributions of these estimated stop locations are summarized in 'BBS_stop_location_uncertainty.csv'.

attr.attrdef: Breeding Bird Survey (BBS) route numbers as specified by the BBS program. Includes all routes from the central United States study region that were conducive to our method and had digitized estimated stop locations available.

BBS stop number as specified by the BBS program. Stops run from 1 to 50 on each route, but we eliminated the last five stops (46-50) because they often occurred beyond the end of 50 km route lines. These are digitized estimates of stop locations derived from a variety of precise (rarely, GPS) and less precise (more commonly, e.g., based on map markings, observer notes, or spacing) methods, from a single (often unspecified) survey year.

This is the number of the autogenerated points that we produced along each BBS route path. It indicates which autogenerated point was nearest a given digitized estimated BBS stop location. The points are placed every 40 meters starting at the route line beginning and are numbered consecutively and so can function as a measure of route distance. Coordinates of autogenerated points are found in a separate .csv file. Distributions of these estimated stop locations are summarized in 'BBS_stop_location_uncertainty.csv'
This is the distance of the nearest autogenerated point from the relevant estimated BBS stop location. In meters.

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing data. These are GPS digitized estimated stop locations for some Wisconsin routes. Note that they apply only to the year collected - stops often move locations or change numbers from year to year.

attr.attrdef: Breeding Bird Survey (BBS) route numbers as specified by the BBS program. Includes all routes from Wisconsin that were conducive to our method and had that had GPS-digitized stop locations available for one of our modeled years.

BBS stop number as specified by the BBS program. Stops run from 1 to 50 on each route, but we eliminated the last five stops (46-50) because they often occurred beyond the end of 50 km route lines. These are digitized estimates of stop locations collected using GPS in a given year but should not be assumed to apply to other years.
Year in which GPS location of this stop was collected. Note that this stop location cannot be assumed to apply to other years.
Method used to collect stop locations. In this file, all are collected by GPS in the field.

edom.edomvd: Observers collected GPS locations of routes in the field. This did not always occur on the same day as the survey.

attr.attrdef: Latitude WGS84
Longitude WGS84

This is the number of the autogenerated points that we produced along each BBS route path. It indicates which autogenerated point was nearest a given digitized BBS stop location in the year indicated. The points are placed every 40 meters starting at the route path beginning and are numbered consecutively and so can function as a measure of route distance. Coordinates of autogenerated points are found in a separate .csv file.
This is the distance of the nearest autogenerated point from the relevant estimated BBS stop location in the specified year. In meters.

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing data. BBS stops can occur at different locations along BBS route paths on different routes and in different years. This file compiles information gleaned from digitized estimates of stop locations across the central United States. It gives distributions of locations of each of the first 45 BBS stops (1-45) both in terms of route distance (meters) and autogenerated point number. Autogenerated points are sequentially numbered and fall every 40 m on BBS route lines. Autogenerated point coordinates for each route and available in 'Autogenerated_BBS_points.csv'. The digitized estimated stop locations used to produce this file are located in 'BBS_stops_nearest_autogen_point.csv'.

attr.attrdef: BBS stop number as specified by the BBS program. Stops run from 1 to 50 on each route, but we eliminated the last five stops (46-50) because they often occurred beyond the end of 50 km route paths. These are from digitized estimated stop locations from a variety of precise (rarely, GPS) and less precise (more commonly, e.g., based on map markings, observer notes, or spacing), from a single (often unspecified) survey year.

This is the number of the autogenerated points that we produced along each BBS route path. It indicates which autogenerated point was nearest a given digitized estimated BBS stop location. The points are placed every 40 meters starting at the route path beginning and are numbered consecutively and so can function as a measure of route distance. Each stop number (first column) is associated with multiple autogenerated points (one each per route for which a digitized estimate of that stop number was available). The distribution of autogenerated point numbers for each stop indicates the distribution of that stop along BBS route paths and thus serves as a measure of location uncertainty. There are thus multiple rows in this data file with the same stop number and autogen point number, indicating that a stop was found nearest that point number on multiple routes with digitized estimated stop locations. The digitized estimated stop locations used to produce this file are located in 'BBS_stops_nearest_autogen_point.csv'.

The distance along a BBS route path at which a stop falls. Autogenerated points (column to left) were placed every 40 meters along each route, starting at 0 m, such that e.g. autogenerated point #3 is (3-1)*40 = 80 m along the route path.

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing data. This gives coordinates and autogenerated point numbers for consecutively numbered points generated every 40 meters along many BBS routes in the central United States. Includes all routes from the central United States study region that were conducive to our method and had digitized estimated stop locations available.

attr.attrdef: Breeding Bird Survey (BBS) route numbers as specified by the BBS program. Includes all routes from the central United States study region that were conducive to our method and had digitized estimated stop locations available.
US State. Values are standard US State two-letter codes

This is the number of the autogenerated points that we produced along each BBS route path. The points are placed every 40 meters starting at the route path beginning and are numbered consecutively and so can function as a measure of route distance.
latitude WGS84
longitude WGS84

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing data. This file summarizes land cover across BBS routes in the central United States by counting pixels of certain merged land cover classes based on the National Land Cover Database (NLCD). It presents pixel counts within a 400 m radius of points generated every 40 m along BBS routes. Uses the NLCD from the year indicated in the 'year' column and file name. Cover classes are merged as detailed in the 'class_merge' column metadata. When paired with the 'BBS_stop_location_uncertainty.csv' file, this file can be used to generate land cover uncertainty distributions for BBS stops. Includes all routes from our modeled region (Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Michigan) that were conducive to our method and had digitized estimated stop locations available.

attr.attrdef: Breeding Bird Survey (BBS) route numbers as specified by the BBS program. Includes all routes from our modeled region (Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Michigan) that were conducive to our method and had digitized estimated stop locations available.

This is the number of the autogenerated points that we produced along each BBS route path. The points are placed every 40 meters starting at the route path beginning and are numbered consecutively and so can function as a measure of route distance. Autogenerated point coordinates for each route are available in 'Autogenerated_BBS_points.csv'.
The year of the National Land Cover Database (NLCD) layer used to generate land cover pixel counts.

Merged land cover classes based on the National Land Cover Database (NLCD). Some original NLCD classes are merged as indicated in the column value metadata. Additional NLCD classes were not used and are not included. Nothing can be assumed about pixel counts of land cover classes that were not included in this column (refer to column class definitions). Note that, to reduce file size, rows with pixel counts of zero (0) for a given land cover at a given stop and route were eliminated. Pixel counts for missing route-stop-land cover-year combinations can thus be assumed to be zero (0) for the land cover classes covered by this file (those in the 'class_merge' column).

edom.edomvd: Combines all of the following original NLCD cover classes: Deciduous Forest; Evergreen Forest; Mixed Forest; Woody Wetlands
Combines all of the following original NLCD cover classes: Grassland/Herbaceous; Pasture/Hay; Sedge/Herbaceous
Combines all of the following original NLCD cover classes: Developed, Open Space; Developed, Low Intensity; Developed, Medium Intensity; Developed, High Intensity
Emergent Herbaceous Wetlands original NLCD class

attr.attrdef: Number of 30-meter pixels in the NLCD layer used that correspond to the land cover category indicated in the 'class_merge' column. Out of a total possible of 529 pixels. Pixel count is within a 400 m radius of the indicated autogenerated point on the indicated BBS route. Note that, to reduce file size, rows with pixel counts of zero (0) for a given land cover at a given stop and route were eliminated. Pixel counts for missing route-stop-land cover-year combinations can thus be assumed to be zero (0) for the land cover classes covered by this file (those in the 'class_merge' column).

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing data. This file summarizes land cover across BBS routes in the central United States by counting pixels of certain merged land cover classes based on the National Land Cover Database (NLCD). It presents pixel counts within a 400 m radius of points generated every 40 m along BBS routes. Uses the NLCD from the year indicated in the 'year' column and file name. Cover classes are merged as detailed in the 'class_merge' column metadata. When paired with the 'BBS_stop_location_uncertainty.csv' file, this file can be used to generate land cover uncertainty distributions for BBS stops. Includes all routes from our modeled region (Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Michigan) that were conducive to our method and had digitized estimated stop locations available.

attr.attrdef: Breeding Bird Survey (BBS) route numbers as specified by the BBS program. Includes all routes from our modeled region (Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Michigan) that were conducive to our method and had digitized estimated stop locations available.

This is the number of the autogenerated points that we produced along each BBS route path. The points are placed every 40 meters starting at the route path beginning and are numbered consecutively and so can function as a measure of route distance. Autogenerated point coordinates for each route are available in 'Autogenerated_BBS_points.csv'.
The year of the National Land Cover Database (NLCD) layer used to generate land cover pixel counts.

Merged land cover classes based on the National Land Cover Database (NLCD). Some original NLCD classes are merged as indicated in the column value metadata. Additional NLCD classes were not used and are not included. Nothing can be assumed about pixel counts of land cover classes that were not included in this column (refer to column class definitions). Note that, to reduce file size, rows with pixel counts of zero (0) for a given land cover at a given stop and route were eliminated. Pixel counts for missing route-stop-land cover-year combinations can thus be assumed to be zero (0) for the land cover classes covered by this file (those in the 'class_merge' column).

edom.edomvd: Combines all of the following original NLCD cover classes: Deciduous Forest; Evergreen Forest; Mixed Forest; Woody Wetlands
Combines all of the following original NLCD cover classes: Grassland/Herbaceous; Pasture/Hay; Sedge/Herbaceous
Combines all of the following original NLCD cover classes: Developed, Open Space; Developed, Low Intensity; Developed, Medium Intensity; Developed, High Intensity
Emergent Herbaceous Wetlands original NLCD class

attr.attrdef: Number of 30-meter pixels in the NLCD layer used that correspond to the land cover category indicated in the 'class_merge' column. Out of a total possible of 529 pixels. Pixel count is within a 400 m radius of the indicated autogenerated point on the indicated BBS route. enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing data. This file summarizes land cover across BBS routes in the central United States by counting pixels of certain merged land cover classes based on the National Land Cover Database (NLCD). It presents pixel counts within a 400 m radius of points generated every 40 m along BBS routes. Uses the NLCD from the year indicated in the 'year' column and file name. Cover classes are merged as detailed in the 'class_merge' column metadata. When paired with the 'BBS_stop_location_uncertainty.csv' file, this file can be used to generate land cover uncertainty distributions for BBS stops. Includes all routes from our modeled region (Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Michigan) that were conducive to our method and had digitized estimated stop locations available.

attr.attrdef: Breeding Bird Survey (BBS) route numbers as specified by the BBS program. Includes all routes from our modeled region (Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Michigan) that were conducive to our method and had digitized estimated stop locations available.

This is the number of the autogenerated points that we produced along each BBS route path. The points are placed every 40 meters starting at the route path beginning and are numbered consecutively and so can function as a measure of route distance. Autogenerated point coordinates for each route are available in 'Autogenerated_BBS_points.csv'.
The year of the National Land Cover Database (NLCD) layer used to generate land cover pixel counts.

Merged land cover classes based on the National Land Cover Database (NLCD). Some original NLCD classes are merged as indicated in the column value metadata. Additional NLCD classes were not used and are not included. Nothing can be assumed about pixel counts of land cover classes that were not included in this column (refer to column class definitions). Note that, to reduce file size, rows with pixel counts of zero (0) for a given land cover at a given stop and route were eliminated. Pixel counts for missing route-stop-land cover-year combinations can thus be assumed to be zero (0) for the land cover classes covered by this file (those in the 'class_merge' column).

edom.edomvd: Combines all of the following original NLCD cover classes: Deciduous Forest; Evergreen Forest; Mixed Forest; Woody Wetlands
Combines all of the following original NLCD cover classes: Grassland/Herbaceous; Pasture/Hay; Sedge/Herbaceous
Combines all of the following original NLCD cover classes: Developed, Open Space; Developed, Low Intensity; Developed, Medium Intensity; Developed, High Intensity
Emergent Herbaceous Wetlands original NLCD class

attr.attrdef: Number of 30-meter pixels in the NLCD layer used that correspond to the land cover category indicated in the 'class_merge' column. Out of a total possible of 529 pixels. Pixel count is within a 400 m radius of the indicated autogenerated point on the indicated BBS route. Note that, to reduce file size, rows with pixel counts of zero (0) for a given land cover at a given stop and route were eliminated. Pixel counts for missing route-stop-land cover-year combinations can thus be assumed to be zero (0) for the land cover classes covered by this file (those in the 'class_merge' column).

cntaddr.address: Denver Federal Center, Building 810, Mail Stop 302

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Biological Data Profile of the Content Standard for Digital Geospatial Metadata
